abstract.para: This document introduces the key concepts of Information Sharing Planning, gives a tour of the Channels ISP web application, outlines a planning method, and briefly compares Information Sharing Planning with Business Process Management.

chapter.title: Motivation and definitions
chapter.para: Organizations operate in an increasingly inter-connected and inter-dependent world. Systemic risks are growing. Organizations must network to compete in a global marketplace. They can no longer respond to major crisis nor can they seize global business opportunities on their own. Success now largely depends on the timely and targeted sharing of information within and between organizations.
During a crisis, information will not spontaneously flow as needed. Maintaining contact lists is not enough; organizations must plan ahead and create actionable information sharing procedures.
Information Sharing Planning provides a framework and method for designing and improving the information sharing procedures required to successfully manage systemic risks and seize opportunities.

section.title: In a nutshell

para.emphasis: Information Sharing Planning captures, analyzes and deploys knowledge of how organizations need to share information to mitigate systemic risks and seize opportunities from anticipated events.

section.para: Information Sharing Planning (ISP) produces information sharing procedures for event preparedness, response and recovery. Information Sharing Plans capture commitments to share the information required for organizations to fulfill their missions.
ISP uncovers:

listitem.para: who needs what information, and why and when,
who has or can produce needed information, and how and when,
what information should flow, and when and how,
the consequences of not sharing according to Plan.

section.para: The deliverables of ISP are:

listitem.para: documented information sharing procedures
individualized information sharing 'playbooks',
information flow analytics and visualizations,
detected information sharing gaps, bottlenecks and single points of failure.

section.para: It is important understand that an Information Sharing Plan is not an action plan. Its objective is not to dictate a sequence of actions. Information sharing planning concerns itself exclusively with capturing the information sharing required according to circumstance so that necessary tasks can be carried out successfully.

However, task sequencing is not entirely absent from ISP. A task may require information produced by another task that would then necessarily precede it. These sequencing constraints do not typically apply to all tasks and they certainly do not dictate a unique ordering for all tasks. In any case, attempting to define an action plan for organizations that don't have a central authority is more often than not an exercise in futility. What really matters here is capturing what needs to be done, what information is required and produced, and how and when it should or should not be shared.

section.title: Definitions
section.para: An Information Sharing Plan captures the information sharing procedures that people and systems in roles of responsibility are expected to apply in order to fulfill the missions of their organizations before, during and/or after certain types of events. A Plan is comprised of tasks and information flows. Tasks manage risks, achieve gains and/or contribute information to other tasks. Information flows connect tasks that produce information with tasks that require it.
An Information Sharing Plan can be abstracted from a specific context (a context is a collection of organizations with people and systems in their employ) so as to make the Plan generally applicable.
An event in ISP is something that happens or has happened somewhere and that introduces risks to organizations or to their missions.

A goal is either a risk or a gain. A goal is associated with the pre-, co- or post- event phase of an anticipated event. A risk is a possible, negative outcome and it is categorized according to an actuarial taxonomy of risks, and it is rated as more or less severe. A gain is the flip side of a risk. It is a possible positive outcome, and it is categorized by a taxonomy that mirrors the risk taxonomy. A gain is rated as either low, medium or high.

A goal is either a risk or a gain. A goal is associated with the pre-, co- or post- event phase of an anticipated event. A risk is a possible, negative outcome and it is categorized according to an actuarial taxonomy of risks, and it is rated as more or less severe. A gain is the flip side of a risk. It is a possible positive outcome, and it is categorized by a taxonomy that mirrors the risk taxonomy. A gain is rated as either low, medium or high.

Information sharing plans will typically deal with more than one phase of more that one type of event. Because plans can become quite large, planners break them into smaller, more manageable units of planning called segments.

An information sharing segment covers one phase of one type of event, and it will typically focus on just a few goals of organizations. Segments usually depend on other segments. Two segments are co-dependent when information produced by a task in one segment is consumed by a task in the other, or when a task in one segment initiates the event phase covered by the other segment.

Segments are planning artifacts. They are not meaningful to non-planners. An information sharing playbook ignores segment boundaries when aggregating a person or system's task assignments and sharing commitments.

A task in ISP describes something done somewhere for some purpose by a person or system in a role of responsibility on behalf of an organization. The people or systems carrying out tasks are profiled by name, role, jurisdiction and/or organization. The executor of a task may be profiled only partially so that more than one person or system match the profile and get assigned to the task. According to a tasks' definition, those assigned to the task are expected to carry it out either as a team or on their own.
Tasks are considered useful if they:

listitem.para: achieve risk mitigation or gains,
initiate or terminate (phases of) events,
or produce information needed by other useful tasks.

section.para: Tasks can be triggered or terminated by:

listitem.para: awareness of events,
notifications they receive,
requests for information they receive.

section.para: Information flows link tasks that produce information to tasks that consume it. A flow is characterized by:

listitem.para: the information communicated (down to its elements, each with optional secrecy classifications and optional sourcing and handling instructions),
the mode of communication (request vs notification, unicast vs broadcast),
a list of preferred communication media (phone, face-to-face etc.),
the impacts, if any, the communication may have (it might trigger or terminate a task),
policies that mandate or prohibit sharing.

section.para: Task assignments are determined by matching the tasks specified in the Plan with the people and systems profiled in a context. People and systems are bound by information sharing commitments when they are assigned tasks that produce information consumed by other tasks.
The information sharing procedures captured by a Plan are the task assignments plus the information sharing commitments of all persons and systems in context.
An information sharing playbook is the sum of all information sharing procedures in a Plan for a given person or system.

Plans, segments, tasks, information needs, capabilities and flows are defined in terms of actual or types of agents, places, roles, organizations, events, communication media and phases of events. These are called entities. An entity in ISP is grab-all concept for something not planned that can be unambiguously referenced by name. Entities may themselves be defined in terms of other entities (an organization assigns roles to the persons it employs and systems it administers, etc.).

Actual entities (“Jane Smith”, “ACME Inc.”, “Morristown, Morris County, NJ, USA” etc.) are categorized by types of entities (“Senior executive”, “Corporation”, “City” etc.). Entity types can refine other entity types (a “Senior executive” is an “Executive”).

An agent is either a person or an information processing system (system for short). A system is capable of sending notifications, answering queries, receiving notifications or sending queries. An agent has contact information. An agent's clearance is a list of secrecy classifications. A secrecy classification has a name (“NATO”) and an ordered list of secrecy levels (“Restricted”, “Confidential”, “Secret”, “Focal Top Secret”, “Cosmic Top Secret”).

An organization is a group of agents organized to accomplish a mission. An organization assigns roles of responsibility to the persons and systems that act on its behalf. An organization has contact information and may contain other organizations. An organization may have information sharing agreements with other organizations to formalize the sharing commitments its members has with members of other organizations.
A role is a set of powers and responsibilities assigned by an organization to an agent acting on behalf of the organization. A role assignment may be restricted to a jurisdiction.

A place is either a geographical area (some city, county, state, country, natural preserve etc.) or a known location (some train station, building etc.). A place can be contained in another (for example, a building can be in a campus). An event and an event type can both be scoped to a place.

A phase names a time period relative to an event. A phase of an event is either CONFIDENTIAL - Copyright (C) 2010 Mind-Alliance Systems. All Rights Reserved. 8 set to before, during or after the event. Typical phases are “Preparing”, “Responding” and “Recovering”.

A communication medium is how agents transmit information. A medium is either unicast (transmits to a single, known agent), multicast (transmits to multiple, known agents) or broadcast (little to no control over who receives the transmission). Communication media may or may not be technology-based. “Telephone”, “Email”, “Instant Messaging” are examples of unicast communication media, and so is “Face-to-face”. “Notification system” and “Meeting” are both multicast media. “Television”, “Radio” and “PA System” are examples of broadcast media. A communication medium can delegate transmissions to other media (for example, VoIP can interface with Telephones). The security of a medium is expressed in terms of secrecy classifications.

ISP identifies more than 60 different kinds of issues about tasks, information flows, entities and entire segments and plans. There are issues of validity (definition errors), completeness (missing Plan elements) and robustness (something that makes the Plan failure-prone). An issue has a description, a list of suggested remediations, and a severity level.

section.title: Channels basics
section.para: Channels is a collaborative Web application for building, analyzing and deploying Information Sharing Plans.

Each Information Sharing Plan has one development version (the only one that can be modified), possibly one production version (the only one participants can access to view their playbooks), and zero or more retired versions (prior production versions).

section.title: User roles
section.para: Channels recognizes three user roles: administrators, planners and Plan participants. Administrators assign planners and participants to plans hosted by a Channels instance. Planners jointly develop, review and deploy information sharing plans. Participants view their playbooks and respond to surveys from planners about issue resolutions.
An administrator can:

listitem.para: add new plans to Channels,
assign users to plans and change their user roles,
do what any planner or participant can do, but for all Plans.

section.para: A planner can:

listitem.para: view assigned plans (all versions),
modify the development version of an assigned Plan,
view the reports from an assigned Plan (all versions),
view all playbooks from an assigned Plan (all versions),
vote with other planners to put the development version of an assigned Plan into production,
launch, access and close online surveys of selected planners and participants about issues in an assigned Plan.

section.para: A participant can:

listitem.para: view his/her playbook from the production version of an assigned Plan,
access and respond to online surveys.

section.title: Logging in and selecting a Plan and segment
section.para: When accessing Channels, an unrecognized user is presented with a login screen.

After logging in, a user with planning privileges (a planner) accesses the Plan Editor. A participant is directed to his/her playbook (see section 3.15). For a planner, the editor opens on the development version of an assigned Plan.
When the Plan Editor is first accessed, Channels pre-selects a segment and a task within it. The task with its “receive” and “send” information flows are shown “collapsed” and summarized.

A planner can at any time select to see another version of the Plan, if any. A planner can also switch to another assigned Plan. Only the development version of a Plan can be modified; retired and production versions are “read-only” (all form fields are disabled, no survey can be launched).

A planner can at any time select which segment within a Plan to view or work on. The tasks and information flows of the selected segment are visualized as a flow map (a directed graph). The selected task is highlighted (by a gray rectangle) in the flow map.
Flow maps can be quite large. A planner can maximize a flow map to see more of it without needing to scroll. Whether maximized or not, a flow map can be zoomed out to fit within the available space.

info.title: Plan editor with flow map made to fit

section.para: Tasks and flows are drawn in red if they have known issues. Green and red traffic lights represent the start and end of the event phase covered by the segment. Tasks that are triggered by the start of the segment are connected to the green traffic light icon. Tasks that terminate the event phase are linked to the red traffic light.

Information flows (information shared), information needs (information needed for carrying out a task) and information capabilities (shareable information produced by carrying out a task) are shown as arrows. Single-headed arrows represent notifications. Double-headed arrows are requests, with the empty arrow head pointing to the task that consumes the information request, and with the full arrow head pointing to the task that consumes the answer (the requested information flows to it).

Dots indicate to-be-determined tasks. An arrow from a task to a dot represents an information capability of the task (information produced by the task that can be shared for use in other tasks). An arrow from a dot to a task represents an information need of the task (the task needs information possibly produced by other tasks).
Tasks with a blue background denote remote tasks, that is, tasks from another segment that are connected by sharing flows to tasks in the selected segment.
When a task is selected in a maximized flow map, the flow map is automatically de-maximized to show the summaries of the selected task and those of its flows.

section.title: Editing tasks and flows
section.para: When a task is expanded, its summary is replaced by a form with fields for the editable attributes of the task. The “sends” of the task (information shared by the task plus its information capabilities) and the “receives” of the task (information shared with the task plus its information needs) can also each be expanded into their edit forms.

A task is defined by first naming it. It is further defined by stating where it is to be executed, by whom, in what role, for what jurisdiction, and on behalf of what organization. Any of the location, agent, jurisdiction, role, and organization (entities) that specify a task can be left unnamed so as to imply that more than one agent can be assigned to the task. When the entities are named, the names can identify actual entities (Morritown, NJ, John Doe, ACME etc.) or types of entities (a city, a certified technician, a corporation etc.).
The execution of a task can be set to be “as a team” to indicate that all assignees are to work together when carrying out the task. By default, assignees are each to execute the task independently.

A task is also described by how long it normally takes to complete, whether it repeats and how quickly, and whether it starts automatically with the segment (implying that the assigned agents would become aware of the onset of the event phase on their own).
The purpose of a task can be stated as terminating the event phase of the segment, mitigating one or more risks or achieve gains within the segment's scope.
Related reference and policy documents can be attached to the task either by URL or by uploading them. Finally, the task can be given a brief, informal description.

When editing a “receive” or a “send”, the information needed, produced or to be shared is named and its elements are enumerated, and each assigned individual secrecy classifications and optional sourcing and handling instructions.
The mode of communication is given as either notification or by-request (push or pull).

If an information flow (information that's shared) is a notification, then it can be made a broadcast (information will be shared with all agents assigned to the target task) or a unicast (information will be shared with at least one agent assigned to the target task).

Keep in mind that an information flow that is a “send” to a task producing shared information is the same information flow that is a ”receive” to the task consuming the shared information. One is looking at one flow from its two ends.

An information flow is created by first adding an information need to a task (if necessary), then adding an information capability of the same name in another (also if necessary), and then connecting the need to the capability or vice-versa by setting the “from” or “to” field to the other task.

A communication delay is set either to zero (communication is to happen without delay) or to some finite time interval. For an information need, the delay represents the timeliness requirement for being notified or for getting a response to a request. For an information capability, the delay represents how quickly the information could be produced and communicated. For a sharing flow, the delay represents a “quality of service” commitment.

The communication channels over which the information is to flow can be set for both an information need, and for a notification information flow but only when viewed from the notified task. The same is true for a requested information flow when viewed from the task that responds to a request. Alternate communication channels are listed in order of preference.

The communication channels over which the information is to flow can be set for both an information need, and for a notification information flow but only when viewed from the notified task. The same is true for a requested information flow when viewed from the task that responds to a request. Alternate communication channels are listed in order of preference.

When editing a “send” or “receive”, a planner can set whether sharing would normally trigger or terminate a task. A notification could trigger or terminate the receiving task. It could also terminate the sending task, if sending the notification concludes the task that produced the information. A request could trigger the task that produces the requested response.

Planners can attach documents to a “send” or “receive”. A document can be a reference (it documents), a mandating policy (it obligates sharing), a prohibiting policy (it prohibits sharing), a multiple policy (contains language that imposes obligations and restrictions) or it can be an image provided as an illustration (for example, a screenshot). If an information flow has a prohibiting policy attached to it then there can not be any implied sharing commitment.
As with any Plan elements, a planner can add issues to those detected about tasks or its “sends” or “receives”. Manually added issues can be removed.

section.title: Segment scoping
section.para: Planners can edit the scope, name and description of a segment. A segment's edit form is accessed by selecting “About segment” from the top-most “Show” menu.

This opens a Details view on the selected segment where it can be renamed and where the phase and event it references can be changed. As with any other kind of Plan element, reference and policy documents can be attached to a segment.

The scope of a segment is further defined by identifying and describing a set of goals of organizations that relate to the segment's event phase. Goals can be risks to be mitigated or gains to be achieved. These goals are expected to be realized by tasks in the segment. Risks can also be curtailed by tasks that terminate the event phase. To be considered useful, tasks that do not curtail nor mitigate a risk or do not make gains are expected to at least provide information that is directly or indirectly needed by tasks that do.

The Goals view of a segment lets planners define the goals of organizations that are in scope. Goals can be added and removed. A goal is for an organization either to mitigate a risk or to make a gain. A goal is given a type (picked from a taxonomy of risks or gains), an importance (minor, major, severe for risks, low, medium or high for gains), the identity of the organization (either an actual organization or a type of organization), and whether the goal goes away when the event phase covered by the segment terminates.
The tasks that mitigate a given risk or achieve a goal in scope can be listed, sorted and navigated to.
The Map view locates on a Google® map all tasks in the segment that specify geo-locatable locations. The geo-mapping of elements is available throughout Channels.

section.title: Editing and analyzing entities
section.para: A new entity (an agent, role, organization, place, event, phase or communication medium) is automatically created whenever it is first referenced by name. Channels requires that all entities of a given kind be assigned unique names (John Smith, John Smith (1), John Smith (2) etc.).

Recall that the definitions of Plan elements can reference actual entities (ACME Corporation, Peter Sanchez, Morristown NJ) and types of entities (a corporation, a certified emergency technician, a city). An entity can only be tagged with entity types of its own kind (Warehouse A can be tagged as a building but not as a senior executive). Both actual entities and entity types can be edited. An editable and analytical view of an actual entity or type of entity can be opened from wherever it is referenced.

Keep in mind that events, roles and communication media in a Plan are always types. There is no actual event in a Plan because events are always anticipated. There is no such thing as an “actual role” because roles are always concepts. Communication media are also always types because a Plan only cares about the class of a communication medium.
The Details view of an entity enables a planner to change the entity's name, description, and types.

Each kind of entity has additional, specific attributes that can also be set. For example, a planner editing an actual organization can define its mission, and set its location, contact information, and parent organization. A planner can enforce that any sharing commitment by the organization with another be covered by an agreement, and that there be at least one known agent for each referenced role assigned by the organization. A planner edits the organization's employment roster of agents by either confirming employment implied by task in segments and assigning titles. A planner can also directly add new employees with their titles, roles and jurisdictions.

Cross-organizational sharing commitments are inferred from information flows in the Plan. A sharing agreement may or may not exist for a sharing commitment that crosses organizational boundaries. An unconfirmed agreement for a cross-organizational sharing commitment is an issue if such agreements are required for the organization. When viewing an organization, a planner can see the sharing commitments the organization makes with other organizations and confirm whether each commitment is covered or not by an agreement.
In the Details view of any kind of entity, references to the entity are listed as a filterable and paged index. Issues about the entity, if any, are enumerated at the bottom of the view.

In the Details view of an actual agent (as opposed to a type of agent), the agent, if it is a person and not a system, can be related to a user. The user, if not a planner, will be able to request to view his or her playbook (the agent's playbook) from the production version of the Plan. The agent can be declared to be a person or system, and given contact information (communication media with addresses where applicable) as well as clearances (secrecy classifications).

When editing a place from within the Details view, a planner can identify what other place, if any, contains it. A planner can also give the place a street address, postal code and a geoname. If the geoname is ambiguous, more specific geonames are offered for selection.

When editing a communication medium, a planner can set the transmission mode to either unicast (one -to-one), multicast (one-to-many) or broadcast (one-to-any), unless the mode is already implied by another medium this one is tagged with (to make it a special case of the tagging medium). The address pattern is a “regular expression”1 that constrains the form an “address” can take for this medium. A planner can identify the media, if any, this one interfaces with as it carries out transmissions from sender to receiver. Here again, some of the interfaced media might be implied from another medium this one is tagged with. Finally, a planner can describe the security of the communication medium in terms of security classifications. Qualifying a medium as “US Gov/Top Secret” means that Top Secret information can be transmitted securely over this medium.

The Network view is available on agents, roles, and organizations. It displays a network graph depicting how the entity is connected by information flows to other entities of the same kind. This analytical view allows a planner to filter the information flows to, say, show only the ones from tasks executed by a specific role. The network graph is navigable. The list of flows can be further filtered, sorted and paged. Listed flows can also be navigated to.
The Issues view collects and filters issues that are about an entity or that are related to it. Waived issues can be included in or excluded from the sortable, page-able list of issues.

Surveys, whether ongoing, closed, or to-be-created, are accessible from each listed issue. Only planners can launch or close surveys. A survey gathers the opinions of planners and non-planners alike on how a particular issue should be remediated.

section.title: Acquiring and releasing edit locks
section.para: More than one planner can concurrently work on a Plan. To prevent “collisions” where two planners are attempting to modify the same Plan element at the same time, only one planner is permitted to modify any given task, flow or entity at a time.

When a planner opens an edit form on a Plan element, Channels attempts to grab an edit lock on behalf of the planner for that Plan element. If another planner already owns the lock, the form is shown to the first planner with the editable fields disabled.
A lock on a task, flow or entity owned by a planner is released when the planner collapses or closes its edit form. An inactive or logged out planner eventually loses all acquired locks.
A planner waiting for edit locks is notified when the locks are released. The planner is then instructed to refresh the editor in order to acquire the locks and enable disabled edit forms.

section.title: Viewing task assignments and sharing commitments
section.para: Recall that tasks are defined in terms of agents, roles, places, and organizations, and that these entities can be actual or types. A task specification may reference entity types or omit to identify by name an actual agent, role, jurisdiction, etc. so as to encompass more than one possible agent as executor of the task. A task thus defined could be assigned to more than one agent.
A planner can look up the list of agents that are assigned to the task (the task assignments).

Agents are implicitly bound by sharing commitments when they are assigned to tasks that are sources of information flows. A planner can look up the list of sharing commitments inferred by an information flow.

section.title: Assessing the impacts of failure
section.para: Planners can assess what might happen should someone fail at an assigned task or should a commitment to share information be broken. The consequences could be a number of “downstream” tasks failing to make gains or mitigate or eliminate risks as planned.

For the sake of analysis, it is assumed that a failure is always complete; a failed task does not produce any information that may be required by others, and a failed information flow does not transfer any information whatsoever.
A failure can cause a cascade of task failures if tasks directly or indirectly depend critically on or are triggered by information that fails to be produced or to be shared.

Not all sharing failures matter. If an information flow is not critical to a task or does not trigger it, then its failure does not propagate to other tasks. Furthermore, if the target of a flow can get the same information via another, non-failing flow, then the flow's failure does not matter. Finally, if information produced by an agent is necessarily consumed by the same agent then, clearly, failure to share is meaningless.

Failure analysis only concerns itself with the failure of useful tasks, that is, tasks that either achieve stated goals or produce information that triggers or is critical to other tasks that are themselves useful. (Useless tasks are flagged as issues.) Note that a task will terminate a risk if it causes a segment to end (or, more to the point, if it causes the event phase the segment is about to end) and if the risk is said to terminate with the segment.

A planner does “what-if”, failure analysis by selecting a task or by selecting an information flow (“send” or “receive”) and then looking at the consequences should it fail. The planner can take a pessimistic outlook and assume that all redundant information flows would also fail, no matter what.

The result of the analysis is a cascade of failures visualized as a directed graph of information flows, tasks, gains and risks. Risks that would otherwise be mitigated or terminated by failed tasks are shown as color-coded flags. Orange is for severe risks, yellow for major risks and blue for minor risks. Risks that would normally be mitigated by successful tasks are shown connected to these tasks. Risks that would be terminated, should a segment end, are shown connected to red stop lights. Each stop light is itself connected to a failed task that would normally end the segment.
Missed gains are shown as stars and are similarly color-coded by importance, with orange for high, yellow for medium and blue for low.

In addition to the visual map, a tabular list of failed, goal-oriented tasks (the failures that matter) is compiled and presented. The table is paginated and the columns (failing task, segment, impact, goal, magnitude of the loss, and organization impacted) can be sorted.

Failure analysis crosses segment boundaries. A failed task in one segment can cause tasks to fail in other segments. Tasks, flows and goals in segments other than the selected segment are grouped in blue boxes.

section.title: Actions
section.para: Planners can create and remove segments; add, cut, copy and paste tasks, needs, capabilities and flows, connect tasks together with information flows or disconnect them. These actions are all available from “action” menus associated with editable Plan elements.

High-level actions can also be taken whenever applicable. They include “disintermediate” which removes a task that acts as a middleman in a flow, “intermediate” which adds a middleman task to a flow, and “satisfy needs” which automatically connects information needs of a task to matching but untapped information capabilities from other tasks.
Most actions can be undone and redone up and until a planner takes an action that conflicts with the undoing or redoing.

info.title: Adding an intermediate task to a flow

section.title: Adding and building a segment
section.para: When a planner creates a new segment, it is given a default name and a scope.

info.title: Adding a segment to a plan

section.para: It is also initially populated with a single, unspecified task. A task can not be removed if it is the last task in a segment.

A planner would typically first name and describe the segment, set its scope (identify an event phase and goals to be achieved), and edit the lone task. Then, additional tasks would be added, together with their information needs and capabilities. These tasks would be connected via information flows with other tasks in the selected segment or other segments.

section.title: Issue detection and management
section.para: Channels automatically detects more than 60 different kinds of issues. Planners can manually add issues to Plan elements, describe these issues and suggest remediations. Manually added issues can later be removed.

Issue detection and remediation can provide guidance to planners as to what to do next when building a Plan. For example, a newly created segment with its lone task will immediately cause the detection of incompleteness issues. Resolving these incompleteness issues drives the planning process forward.
Some detected issues can be waived by planners if they are considered moot. When waiving an issue of a certain kind about a Plan element, all issues of this kind are also waived for the same element.

section.title: Connecting tasks with sharing flows
section.para: After adding a task, a planner may want to give it one or more information needs, and, for each need, name the information required and list the elements of information.

info.title: Unconnected flow with its elements of information

section.para: When a planner names an information, Channels suggests a list of already used information names that look like or mean something similar to the name being entered. This “semantic proximity”-based, auto-suggest capability leverages the WordNet lexical database and is available throughout Channels.

A planner may want to add an information capability to a task (shareable information produced by the specified task) and then connect it to a matching information need from another task in the selected segment or in another segment.

Connecting a capability with a need is done by selecting a task with a matching need from the “From” drop-down menu in the flow form (and vice-versa). Connecting a need with a capability creates a new information flow but does not remove the connected tasks' capability and need.

When a task has unsatisfied information needs (arrows to red dots), a planner may want to apply the “Satisfy needs” action. This automatically creates information flows with the other tasks in the Plan that can share the needed information.

section.title: Plan definition and analytics
section.para: A planner selects the item “About Plan” in the top “Show” menu to access views about the entire Plan.
The default Plan view is the Details view. Here, planners can change the name of a Plan, add phases and remove unreferenced phases. Planners can also add or view issues about the Plan as a whole.

In the All events view, a planner can add events to the scope of the Plan. A planner can mark an event as an incident if it is caused “outside” of the Plan and not (always) as an outcome of a planned task. There is at least one event defined in a Plan.

In the Secrecy classification view, a planner can define secrecy classifications that are then used to qualify elements of information and to set individual clearances. References to a classification can be listed. Unreferenced classifications can be removed.
In the All organizations view, a planner can identify the organizations that are in the default context of the Plan.

In the All segments view, planners can look at a map of all segments in the Plan. The segments can be grouped by phase or by event. Planners can browse all cross-segment sharing flows as well as all tasks in one segment that start or terminate another segment.
In the Who's who view, planners can browse a directory of all agents involved in the Plan.
In the All issues view, planners can sort, filter and browse all issues currently detected or manually added within the Plan. Surveys on individual issues can be created or accessed from this view.
In the Bibliography view, planners browse all the documents that are attached to Plan elements anywhere in the Plan.
In the Index view, planners can find, filter, sort and navigate to all entities referenced in the Plan.
The Evaluation view gives a summary evaluation of the Plan in terms of categories of issues detected and added by planners.

Finally, the Version view is where planners vote to move the development version of the Plan into production. A unanimous vote is required. Moving a development version into production creates a development version from a copy of the new production version. Planners can be contacted by email from within the view to prompt them to vote.

section.title: Secrecy, security and clearances
section.para: Information classification, the security of communications and the clearances of agents can be important elements of information sharing planning in domains of human endeavor that require the compartmentalization of information. Planners can introduce one or more classification systems to a Plan.
Each classification system has a unique name and consists of a list of classifications (secrecy levels) ranked from highest to lowest.
Agents can be given clearances. Clearances are expressed as classifications (no more than one per classification system).
How secure a communication media type is is defined by the highest classification levels of the information it can transmit without infringing security requirements.
Elements of information shared or to be shared can each be given classification levels as well as indications of the source and special handling instructions.
Secrecy and security issues are automatically detected such as:

listitem.para: Classified information transmitted over an insufficiently secure channel
A commitment to share classified information with an agent who has insufficient clearances
Receiving classified information and then disseminating it with reduced classification

section.title: Surveying planners and participants
section.para: Planners can survey other planners and participants assigned to the current Plan about their preferred remediations for issues that are detected by Channels or that are manually entered by planners.
Channels interfaces with the SurveyGizmo® web service to create, launch, and retire surveys, and to collect responses.
The content of a survey is automatically taken from the issue's description and CONFIDENTIAL - Copyright (C) 2010 Mind-Alliance Systems. All Rights Reserved. 66 suggested remediations.

section.title: Publishing information sharing procedures
section.para: Channels produces on demand an information sharing procedures report and individualized information sharing playbooks for the current Plan. The report is accessible to planners but not to participants.
The report organizes by segments and agents the Plan's task assignments, sharing commitments and related issues, and presents them in a single HTML document suitable for browsing and printing.
The Plan map and the information flow maps shown in the report are reduced to fit. Full-sized Plan map and flow maps can be retrieved as PNGs.
From the header of the report, a planner can narrow the focus to a single segment and/or agent. The inclusion of issues can also be turned on or off.
A participant can only access the information sharing procedures for the agent he or she represents, and only from the production version of a Plan.

section.title: Logging out
section.para: A planner logs out to terminate a Plan editing session. Any edit locks still held at that time are automatically released. The user is then presented with a login page.

section.title: Overview
section.para: Channels encourages and supports a methodical approach to information sharing planning.
The main activities of this method are:

listitem.para: setting the scope of the Plan,
dividing the Plan into segments,
defining tasks and information flows,
defining referenced entities,
closing gaps in the Plan,
addressing other issues,
deploying the current version to participants.

section.para: The method here outlined does not address the politics and project logistics of information sharing planning.
When building a new Information Sharing Plan, planners must first decide on the scope of the Plan. The scope is set by choosing:

listitem.para: the anticipated types of events planned for,
the specific phases (before, during or after) to be covered for each event,
the organizations and roles which involvement is expected.

section.para: Planners divide the Plan into segments. Each segment covers one phase of one event and a small list of risks to organizations. Two segments can cover the same event phase, but not the same goal for the same phase of the same event.

A planner works on one segment at a time and can switch attention to another segment at any time. When working on a segment, tasks and information flows linking tasks are identified and defined so that they together address the risks covered by the segment.

Events, phases, agents, roles, organizations, places, and communication media are collectively called entities. Entities are referenced by name in the definitions of a plan's scope, a segment's coverage, tasks, information flows, and other entities. An entity can be referenced by name prior to being defined. An entity should be defined soon after having first been referenced.
The Plan is best grown by progressively closing gaps (completeness issues) such as those caused by:

listitem.para: events or goals not addressed,
unsatisfied task information needs,
information produced by tasks that is not shared,
tasks to which no known agents are assigned,
information flows with no listed communication media.

section.para: Planners can also be presented with issues other than completeness issues, namely, validity and robustness issues. Planners prioritize the resolution of issues possibly on the basis of their severity. Some types of issues can be waived if deemed “false positives”. When tackling an issue, planners may choose to first survey their peers and participants involved in the Plan about alternate remediation strategies.
The planning process is iterative and non-linear. At any point in time, planners can:

listitem.para: change the scope of a Plan,
add/modify/remove new Plan segments,
add/modify/remove tasks and flows in a segment,
resolve issues,
(re)define referenced entities.

section.para: At any point during the development of a Plan, planners may decide to deploy the current version to participants. If a previous version had already been deployed, it is immediately retired and superseded by the new one. Keep in mind that a Plan is never complete and planning is never done.

section.title: Deciding on the scope of the Plan

listitem.para: What anticipated events are being being planned for?
For each anticipated event:
What type of event is it?
At what place or type of place would the event happen?
What phase of the event is being planned for? Before, during or after the event?
What specific organizations are expected to be involved?
What are their names?
What are their respective missions?
What organizational roles are expected to be assigned tasks in the Plan?
What classification systems will be referenced in the Plan and what are their respective classification levels?
For each planned-for event phase, what goals must be achieved (risks addressed and gains made)?
For each risk:
Select the nature of the risk among:
property damage, property loss , injury, disablement or death , or environmental degradation (a material risk)
or cost increase, lost revenue, asset devaluation, reduced liquidity, reduced credit, increased liability, or fines or penalties (a financial risk)
or delayed delivery, impaired quality, process inefficiency, or supply chain disruption (an operational risk)
or opportunity loss, damage to reputation, loss of competitiveness, or product obsolescence (a strategic risk)
How severe is the risk (minor, major or extreme)?
What organizations or types of organization are at risk, in themselves or their missions?
Does the risk go away when the event phase is over?
For each goal:
Select the nature of the goal among:
property improvement, property acquisition, better health , or environmental improvement (a material gain)
or cost decrease, increased revenue, asset value increase, increased liquidity, increased credit, reduced liability, or reward (a financial gain)
or faster delivery, better quality, improved process efficiency, or improved supply chain (an operational gain)
or opportunity gain, improved reputation, greater competitiveness, or longer product life (a strategic gain)
How great is the gain (low, medium or high)?
What organization or type of organization seeks to achieve a gain, for itself or to further its mission?
Does the goal to achieve a gain go away when the event phase is over?
If the list of goals is long, how should it broken into cohesive sub-lists?
Create and name a segment for each (sub-)list of goals for an event phase in scope.

section.title: Defining tasks and flows in each segment
section.para: A task is either some activity or an act of decision making. A task is expected to either mitigate a risk, end or trigger a a phase of an event or produce information needed by another task. People and systems in scope are assigned to a task based on its specifications.

listitem.para: What tasks could terminate the segment's event phase? (Keep in mind that a task causing an event initiates the its co-event phase and terminates its pre-event phase, and that a task that terminates an event also initiates its post-event phase.)
What tasks would achieve one or more of the Plan's segment's goals?
What tasks start on their own with the event phase of a segment? (It is implied that assignees would not require notification of the event to become aware of it.)
For each task:
Name and describe each identified task.
Specify who would carry out a task:
Give the identity or type of an assigned agent, or not.
Give the organizational role of the explicitly or implicitly assigned agent(s), or not.
Give the jurisdiction for the role, or not.
Give the identity or type of organization of the agent, or not.
How long does it normally take to complete the task? Is the task self-repeating? How long does it take before it repeats?
Where is the task executed?
What goals does it achieve?
What are the information needs of a task?
For each information need of a task:
Name the information needed.
List the elements of information.
For each element of information:
Is the element classified?
Are there special instructions regarding the source or the handling of the element?
State whether the task's assignees expect to receive the needed information via notifications or as answers to requests.
List the communication media by which the needed information will be transmitted.
Give the time constraint for providing the information.
State what effect, if any, getting the information would have on the task:
Is it critical to its success?
Would it start the task?
Could it terminate the task?
What information does a task produce?
For each information produced:
Name the information.
List the elements of information and describe them as above.
State how quickly the information could be shared once available or requested.
State whether or not sharing the information would terminate the task.
Connect with information flows tasks that produce information with other tasks that need it and are allowed to use it.
For each information flow, identify any policy that either mandates it or forbids it.

section.title: Defining named entities
section.para: Entities are usually defined right after they are first referenced by name. In the definitions of tasks, flows, other entities etc. entities is referenced either as types (e.g. a Corporation) or as actual entities (e.g. ACME Inc.). An entity type can not be converted into an actual entity, and vice versa. Note that in ISP, there are no “actual” roles or events. Roles are always types and only types of events can be anticipated and planned for.

listitem.para: For each named actual entity or entity type to be defined:
Give a short description.
Name the entity types, if any, that categorize it.
For an agent (actual, not type):
Is the agent a person or an information system?
What are the agent's clearances, if any?
List the agent's contact information.
For an organization:
What is the organization's mission?
Does the organization have a parent organization?
Where is the organization located?
List the organization's contact information.
Who are the members of the organization that are expected to be involved in the Plan?
For each member:
What's the agent's title?
What roles does the agent play and within what jurisdictions, if any?
Is a formal sharing agreement required for each sharing commitment with another organization?
Is is acceptable for anonymous members of the organization to be assigned to tasks (e.g. “Some account manager at Nadir Insurance Inc. evaluates the claim”?)
For a place:
Is it within another?
Does it have a street address?
Can it be located geographically? If so, where?
For a type of place:
Are places of this type inside where a given planned event happens? Does a given planned event happen inside places of this type?
Are places of this type always inside some given place? Is a given place always inside places of this type?
For a type of communication medium:
Is the medium meant for unicast (transmission to one agent), multicast (transmission to many identified agents), or for broadcast (transmission to any and all agents)?
How are agents identified within this medium (e.g. via email addresses, phone numbers, IM handles etc.)?
Does this medium delegate to or interfaces with other media? Which ones?
How secure is the medium in terms of secrecy classifications?

section.title: Growing the Plan by closing gaps
section.para: A Plan can be grown by methodically systematically resolving completeness issues.

listitem.para: If no Plan segment addresses a phase of an event in scope, create such a segment.
If no goal is within the scope of a segment, add one.

If a risk is not mitigated or by any task and no task eliminates it (by terminating the event phase of the segment), then identify or introduce a task that does either. Or consider removing the risk from the scope of the segment.
If a stated gain with the scope of a segment is not achieved by any task, then identify or introduce a task that does so. Or consider removing the gain from the scope of the segment.
If an information need of a task is unsatisfied, identify or introduce a task that produces the needed information and would share it. (Then connect the tasks with a flow.)
If a task produces information that's never shared, identify or introduce a task that needs it and would consume it. Then connect with a flow. Or consider removing this capability from the task.

If a task is not useful (it produces no shared information and achieves no goal), see if it should achieve a goal, or could terminate the event phase, or share information it produces with a task that is useful. If not, consider removing the task.
If a task has no assignment (no known agent matches it), consider adding task-matching members to known organizations, or consider adding organizations to the plan with task-matching members.

section.title: Resolving validity and robustness issues
section.para: Validity issues are caused by incorrect definitions (they are bugs in the Plan). Robustness issues are detected weaknesses in a Plan that make it failure-prone.
Validity issues should be corrected as soon as they are detected.

listitem.para: What are the most pressing issues?
For a given issue:
Can the issue be waived? Should it be waived (false positive)?
What are the options for remediation?
Should other planners and selected participants be surveyed about remediation?
What's the appropriate remediation?

section.title: Deploying to participants
section.para: Work on a Plan is always done on its development version. There is always one and only one development version of a Plan. At some point the planners may agree that the development version should be deployed into production. Note that participants can only get their playbooks from the production version of a Plan.

When all planners vote in favor of deployment, a new production version is released, superseding any prior production version which is then retired. A copy is taken and made the new development version.

listitem.para: Is the development version of the Plan ready for release into production?
Is a new production release warranted?

section.title: Information Sharing Planning and Business Process Management
section.para: The most frequently asked question about Information Sharing Planning is How does it differ from Business Process Management?
To answer this question, one must first consider that Information Sharing Planning (ISP) is part of something larger called Information Sharing Management.

Information Sharing Management (ISM) is a set of technologies and best practices that help communities of organizations share information more effectively in order to manage risks when preparing for, responding to, and recovering from actual events. Information Sharing Planning (ISP) produces the information sharing procedures that organizations apply when doing ISM. ISP analyzes these procedures for continuous improvement.

Business Process Management (BPM) helps enterprises become more efficient, more effective and more agile in how they operate. Business Process Modeling captures and analyzes their business processes for continuous improvement.
Because ISP relates most closely to Business Process Modeling, the question should be recast to How does Information Sharing Management differ from Business Process Management?
Other questions are Can ISM and BPM be used together?, and How do the markets for BPM and ISM compare?

section.title: Differences
section.para: BPM and ISM tackle different problems from different perspectives.

BPM focuses 'inward' on a single (but possibly extended) enterprise. It looks at how the enterprise responds internally to events, and at how it renders services to its customers. The end is maximizing value creation while minimizing costs. The means is business process improvement.

ISM focuses 'outward' on (often ad hoc) communities of organizations. It looks at how organizations depend on one another to get the information they need to execute tasks that achieve organizational goals. The end is minimizing the impacts of systemic risks and maximizing the capture of opportunities. The means is better information sharing procedures.

While there is conceptual overlap (both ISM and BPM involve tasks, events and communications) and even though they both use somewhat similar-looking visualizations (directed graphs), ISM and BPM have very different world views. BPM looks at the operations of an enterprise, whereas ISM looks at the information flows within a community of organizations. They also differ in their goals. BPM optimizes enterprise value creation whereas ISM reduces the impacts of systemic risks.

section.title: Similarities
section.para: ISM and BPM are structurally similar in a number of ways.
Both BPM and ISM are concerned with optimization. BPM optimizes the design and execution of business processes, whereas ISM optimizes information sharing procedures and their application.

BPM and ISM each has a modeling component (business process modeling, information sharing planning) and a deployment component (modeled business processed are deployed as work flows, information sharing plans are deployed as information sharing procedures).

Both BPM and ISM integrate with existing systems and technologies. BPM integrates with EAI (Enterprise Application Integration), SOA (Service-Oriented Architecture) and EBA (Event-Based Architecture) technologies. ISM integrates primarily with Communication Technologies, Enterprise Directories and SOA.
Finally, both BPM and ISM require the participation of analysts. BPM involves 'business process engineers' and ISM involves 'information sharing planners'.

section.title: Integration
section.para: Because BPM and ISM have such different world views, we should not expect either to eventually absorb the other.

There are however significant points of interaction between BPM and ISM. To name a few, business processes can be driven by events that become known through information sharing, and the business processes executed when carrying out risk-mitigating tasks can be optimized.
It is reasonable to assume that BPM and ISM products will, in some future, work together to their mutual benefit.

section.title: Markets
section.para:
“The BPM market is one of the fastest growing software markets, estimated to grow tenfold in five years, from approximately US$500 million in 2006 to US$6 billion in 2011.”
See http://www.oracle.com/technologies/bpm/docs/state-of-bpm-market-whitepaper.pdf
While BPM is a maturing field, ISM is still in its infancy. It is too early to attempt an estimate of how fast the market for ISM could grow or how big it could ultimately become.

However, ISM is applicable to all domains of joint human endeavor, from emergency response to business risk management. With the explosive growth in systemic risks, as underscored by the recent financial crisis, the value proposition of ISM in an increasingly inter-connected world is bound to become compelling.

As BPM products become consolidated among a small number of large vendors, ISM may represent a unique opportunity for small firms to enter and define a new market space. Established BPM vendors might also want to offer BPMintegrated ISM products in order to differentiate themselves from their competitors.
